overview: This breadth subject explores the interactions between insects and humans worldwide and through a multidisciplinary lens. Insects can be harnessed for food, medicine, and construction material. They can inspire architecture and design and have prominent roles in myth and songs and shape language. Insects have inspirated films, performances, music, and visual arts where artists aim to challenge our emotional and aesthetic connection to insects. Insects are both biologically and socially complex, from which important parallels to human biology and societal organisation can be drawn. Despite the importance of insects to humans, insects have been heavily impacted by human leading to enormous insect declines. In this subject, students from disciplines across the university can explore the impacts that insects have on humans and human society by learning from experts across many different fields through a combination of lectures and interactive, hands-on activities. This subject aims to broaden the students' scope in how we understand the multifaceted impacts that insects have on society.
ilo: Analyse the impact of agricultural practices on insects, including pollinators and insect pests
Critically assess the way insects are used in, and influence literature, film, performance art, visual art, and architecture
Contextualise the significance of insects throughout history and across geography
Evaluate the impacts of humans on insect populations to explain dramatic loss in insect biodiversity around the world
generic_skills: Develop an aptitude for continued self-directed learning and become adept at learning in a range of ways, including through information and communication technologies
Critically synthesise and evaluate knowledge across disciplines and confront unfamiliar problems
Engage in meaningful discourse and develop excellent interpersonal and decision-making skills

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: In class participation including group work and mini-quizzes
